'NAICS_2022_6_NAME'] ``` ::: ::: ## Dropping Unnecessary Columns ::: {#beb8135d .cell results='hide' execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true"} # Define columns that are irrelevant or redundant for our analysis columns_to_drop = [ # Tracking and metadata "ID", "LAST_UPDATED_DATE", "LAST_UPDATED_TIMESTAMP", "DUPLICATES", "URL", "ACTIVE_URLS", "ACTIVE_SOURCES_INFO", "SOURCE_TYPES", "SOURCES", # Company raw info "COMPANY_RAW", "COMPANY_IS_STAFFING", # Raw or text-heavy fields "TITLE_RAW", "BODY", # Modeled / derived fields "MODELED_EXPIRED", "MODELED_DURATION", # Educational levels (redundant versions) "EDUCATION_LEVELS", "EDUCATION_LEVELS_NAME", "MIN_EDULEVELS", "MIN_EDULEVELS_NAME", "MAX_EDULEVELS", # Redundant NAICS / SOC codes "NAICS_2022_2", "NAICS_2022_2_NAME", "NAICS_2022_3", "NAICS_2022_3_NAME", "SOC_2", "SOC_3", "SOC_5" ] # Drop columns, ignore if a column is missing df1.drop(columns=columns_to_drop, inplace=True, errors="ignore") # Display the first few rows to confirm df1.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Handling Missing Values ::: {#72c26489 .cell results='hide' execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true"} import seaborn as sns import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import os os.makedirs("figureswxw", exist_ok=True) ``` ::: ::: {#cell-Missing Value Heatmap .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true"} import missingno as msno import matplotlib.pyplot as plt msno.heatmap(df1) plt.title("Missing Values Heatmap") plt.tight_layout() plt.savefig("figureswxw/missing_values_heatmap.png", dpi=300) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Missing values in the dataset](data_cleaning_files/figure-html/missing-value-heatmap-output-1.png){#missing-value-heatmap width=1781 height=1140 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ![](figureswxw/missing_values_heatmap.png){width=100% fig-align='center'} ::: {#d017f986 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true"} # Drop columns with >50% missing values df1.dropna(axis=1, thresh=len(df1) * 0.5, inplace=True) if "SALARY" in df1.columns: df1["SALARY"] = df1["SALARY"].fillna(df1["SALARY"].median()) df1["DURATION"] = df1["DURATION"].fillna(df1["DURATION"].median()) categorical_columns = ["REMOTE_TYPE_NAME", "COMPANY_NAME", "MAX_EDULEVELS_NAME"] for col in categorical_columns: if col in df1.columns: df1[col] = df1[col].fillna("Unknown") df1.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 72498 entries, 0 to 72497 Data columns (total 96 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ results='hide' execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true"} df1.drop_duplicates(subset=["TITLE_CLEAN", "COMPANY_NAME", "CITY_NAME", "POSTED"], inplace=True) df1["REMOTE_TYPE_NAME"].value_counts(dropna=False) df1["EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME"].value_counts(dropna=False) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=20} ``` EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME Full-time (> 32 hours) 68493 Part-time (â‰¤ 32 hours) 2278 Part-time / full-time 972 NaN 17 Name: count, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#451bd4fb .cell results='hide' execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true"} #improve df1["EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME"] = df1["EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME"].replace({ "Part-time (â‰¤ 32 hours)": "Part-time (≤ 32 hours)", "Part-time / full-time": "Part-time / Full-time" }) df1["EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME"] = df1["EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME"].fillna("Unknown") df1["EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME"].value_counts() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=21} ``` EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME Full-time (> 32 hours) 68493 Part-time (≤ 32 hours) 2278 Part-time / Full-time 972 Unknown 17 Name: count, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#a213b341 .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true"} #double check import pandas as pd categorical_columns = [ "EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME", "REMOTE_TYPE_NAME", "COMPANY_NAME", "STATE_NAME", "CITY_NAME", "MAX_EDULEVELS_NAME" ] tables = [] for col in categorical_columns: if col in df1.columns: vc = df1[col].value_counts(dropna=False).rename("count").to_frame() vc.index.name = col tables.append(vc) pd.concat(tables, keys=[t.index.name for t in tables]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=22} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Exploratory Data Analysis ## Remote Type distribution ::: {#04bb908b .cell lable='Remote type distribution Graph' execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true"} remote_counts = df1["REMOTE_TYPE_NAME"].value_counts() plt.figure(figsize=(10,6)) ax = sns.barplot( x=remote_counts.index, y=remote_counts.values, hue=remote_counts.index, palette="Set2" ) plt.title("Distribution of Remote Work Types", fontsize=14) plt.ylabel("Number of Job Postings") plt.xlabel("Remote Type") plt.grid(axis='y', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7) plt.tight_layout() plt.savefig("figureswxw/remote_type_distribution.png", dpi=300) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Remote type distribution](data_cleaning_files/figure-html/cell-12-output-1.png){width=950 height=566 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ![](figureswxw/remote_type_distribution.png){width=100% fig-align='center'} ## Top 10 states by job postings ::: {#dadfed70 .cell lable='Top 10 states' execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true"} import os import pandas as pd import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns df1 = pd.read_csv("data/lightcast_job_postings.csv") city_counts = df1["CITY_NAME"].dropna().value_counts().head(10) plt.figure(figsize=(10,5)) sns.barplot(x=city_counts.index, y=city_counts.values, palette="Accent") plt.title("Top 10 Cities by Job Postings") plt.ylabel("Number of Job Postings") plt.xlabel("City") plt.xticks(rotation=30) plt.grid(axis='y', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7) plt.tight_layout() plt.savefig("figureswxw/top_cities_job_postings.png", dpi=300) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` /var/folders/4f/s815nnpx1_15rfdwxj6cwrtr0000gn/T/ipykernel_8078/1316398421.py:6: DtypeWarning: Columns (19,30) have mixed types. Specify dtype option on import or set low_memory=False. df1 = pd.read_csv("data/lightcast_job_postings.csv") /var/folders/4f/s815nnpx1_15rfdwxj6cwrtr0000gn/T/ipykernel_8078/1316398421.py:11: FutureWarning: Passing `palette` without assigning `hue` is deprecated and will be removed in v0.14.0. Assign the `x` variable to `hue` and set `legend=False` for the same effect. sns.barplot(x=city_counts.index, y=city_counts.values, palette="Accent") ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Remote type distribution](data_cleaning_files/figure-html/cell-13-output-2.png){width=944 height=470 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ![](figureswxw/top_cities_job_postings.png){width=100% fig-align='center'}
